thread.title_full: Texas appeals judge’s order that blocked Medicaid cuts | Dallas Morning News

author: ROBERT T. GARRETT
title: Texas appeals judge’s order that blocked Medicaid cuts
text:
AUSTIN — The state has appealed a judge’s ruling that blocked pay cuts for therapists who treat more than a quarter-million Medicaid patients.
The Health and Human Services Commission said Travis County District Court Judge Tim Sulak misinterpreted state regulations on Medicaid rates.
Sulak’s Sept. 25 order wrongly would require the agency to conduct a full-blown cost analysis before tweaking therapists’ pay in any way, Assistant Attorney General Marc Rietvelt said in a motion filed late Wednesday.
An injunction that halted the rate cuts “interferes with” the commission’s ability to administer Medicaid, the state-federal health insurance program for the poor, Rietvelt said. The state’s lawyer, though, didn’t try to delay a Jan. 18 trial.
Therapy providers and parents of affected children have warned the cuts would cause providers to drop Medicaid patients. By one estimate, 60,000 disabled children and poor seniors would lose services.
However, the commission has insisted it adhered to rate-setting rules. The agency said it simply was following lawmakers’ directive to decrease payments and change policies to deter suspected overuse of therapy services.
Sulak, though, said the commission relied on a “seriously flawed” rate analysis by Texas A&M University researchers. The planned cuts “are probably based on arbitrary criteria that lack adequate or appropriate consideration for the impact on service providers or recipients,” he said.
Three pediatric therapy companies and the families of five disabled children they serve sued the commission. The youngsters suffer from autism, seizure disorders and, in one case, a genetic disorder called Williams syndrome. It causes a heart murmur and developmental delays.
Michael Reiswig, chief executive of Dallas-based Care Options for Kids, one of the plaintiff firms, said Friday that the state failed to follow its own procedures.
“I have no doubt that we will prevail,” Reiswig said in a statement. “But what’s most important right now is to resolve this matter. … The families of these disabled children need to have peace of mind.”
Senate GOP leaders have told the commission it needs to reduce rates, though not so much as to drive providers from the program.
Sulak froze rate cuts scheduled to take effect Oct. 1. If reinstated, they would save about two-thirds of the $350 million the commission needs to squeeze out of Medicaid therapy spending, according to a provision in the two-year state budget passed in May.
The rest would come from policy changes designed to eliminate suspected overuse of therapy by some patients.
Last year, about 242,000 disabled children and seniors received the benefit, according to the commission.
